results.title: Cold war. Vol. 1. Episodes 1-4: Iron curtain
results.creator_credit: Martin Smith, Jeremy Isaacs Productions and Turner Original Productions
results.brief_description: This 24 episode television series presents an excellent biographical history of the Cold War, from the Russian Revolution in 1917 through to the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The battle between super powers America and the Soviet Union is told in great detail through over 600 exclusive interviews and personal narratives, newsreels and archival film footage which attempt to convey to the viewer some of the tensions and conflicts that threatened global peace during those years. Many major historical moments have been captured and provide an insight to the reasons as to how and why the Cold War, the Iron Curtain, East and West, and nuclear weapons became a part of our everyday life, particularly in the 1950s-1960s. Volume one features the first four episodes, covering the period from the Russian Revolution to the breaking of the Berlin blockade in 1949. Once allies against Hitler during World War II, the Soviet Union and the United States became divided over their political and economical ideologies post Nazi Germany with the US pushing for democracy and capitalism and the Soviet favouring expansionism and communism. As Central and Eastern Europe came under the control of Stalin and his puppet governments and the “Iron Curtain” was created, Germany and in particular, Berlin (divided into four occupied zones - US, British, Russian and French) became the focus of attention in the battle for ideological control. Berlin was blockaded and threatened with starvation by Stalin - the West’s response was the Berlin airlift. Meanwhile, to keep up with America’s nuclear capabilities the Soviets detonated their first atomic bomb on 29 August 1949. The American monopoly was over and so began the rise of the Super Powers and decades of confrontation. Narrated by Kenneth Branagh. (For more information see www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war)

results.title: Cold comfort
results.creator_credit: Jack White, Community Education Publication Association, Infomotion and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Cold comfort is a lively and incisive documentary on the local and global consequences of the decision to export Australia’s uranium. Includes the true story of Maralinga, the impact of the Black Mist on the Aboriginal people and revealing footage od the consequences of uranium mining in one of Australia’s magnifican tropical wetlands. Also looks a the nuclear industry in response to global events such as the disasters at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl. Narrated by Jennifer Robinson.

results.title: Codling strikes at dusk
results.brief_description: Shows the fight against the codling moth, a pest which costs Australia about $2,000,000 each year. The film illustrates the life cycle of the moth; eggs laid in the calix of hard fruit become larvae, eat into the fruit, and finally enter the dormant chrysalid stage. Metamorphosed into moths, they lay eggs to complete the cycle - twice each year. Shows the ways in which the moth is introduced into unaffected areas.

results.title: Code Names (2001-present)
results.brief_description: Trevor Paglen’s Code Names exists as a list of words, phrases and terms that designate classified military programs. These include classified exercises and units, intelligence programs, information compartments and Pentagon “Special Access Programs.” Installed in downtown Syracuse, Code Names functions as a meditation on language and advertising whose product is foreign to the general population. The contents of the piece become metaphors for the unknown and ask the audience to ponder what exactly they mean.

constellations_other.name: Orwell & Snowden
constellations_other.description: Explores Orwell as a representation of the NSA, and the infamous Snowden leak.

results.title: Code name Snake's Eye
results.brief_description: A story of a marine commando exercise; a combined operation of ships, planes, frogmen and commandos. A coastal town with the code name “Snake’s Eye” is the objective. Frogmen-parachutists drop from the sky and set to work under the sea; waves of strike aircraft are catapulted into action from a carrier; mass troops are landed by naval helicopters and assault landing craft; commandos are seen taking part in a breathtaking cliff-assault. The action demonstrates the astonishing versatility of the men of the Royal Marines as they go into combat on land, at sea and in the air.

results.title: Cockleshell Bay
results.brief_description: A series of short animated stories about Robin and Rosie Cockle who move to Cockleshell Bay with their parents to set up a guest house. Whilst there they befriend old Mr Ship and Gran Routie who help them in their play. Rated: G

results.title: Cocaine pain
results.creator_credit: J. Gary Mitchell and J Gary Mitchell Film Company
results.brief_description: This film is a documentary that takes a startling look at coke addiction. It examines how cocaine dominates the life of the users, damages their health, impairs their mental capabilities, alienates their friends and families, and consumes millions of their dollars.

results.title: Coal Dust the Invisible Killer
results.brief_description: High productivity at the coalface means increased dust, a major health hazard to the miner. Using diagrams and an actual lung a doctor explains how and what diseases are caused by prolonged exposure to coal dust, and answers key questions of concern to every miner. Strong emphasis is given to suppressing dust at source through effective ventilation and water sprays, combines with statutory monitoring of dust, regular X-Ray and medical examinations. Protection today prevents pneumoconiosis tomorrow.

results.title: Coal and the nineteenth century
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: Dr. Colin Russell considers the use of coal as a raw material. The six sections of the film deal with different products resulting from the decomposition of coal, looking at both the manufacturing processes and the social impact. Wherever possibl
